title: Meore Dasi
text:
Meore Dasi (; "Second Group") was the name for a group of <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgian</a> <a href="liberalism">liberal</a> <a href="intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a> that existed in the latter part of the 19th century, when <a href="Georgia%20within%20the%20Russian%20Empire">Georgia was part</a> of the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>. Founded in 1869 by <a href="Giorgi%20Tsereteli%20%28writer%29">Giorgi Tsereteli</a> and <a href="Petre%20Umikashvili">Petre Umikashvili</a>, it was a contrast to the <a href="Pirveli%20dasi">Pirveli dasi</a> (; "First Group") that was based around <a href="Ilia%20Chavchavadze">Ilia Chavchavadze</a> and was one of the first Georgian nationalist groups to exist.
Responding to the new economic and political currents in European life, the meore dasi members, such as Tsereteli, <a href="Niko%20Nikoladze">Niko Nikoladze</a>, and <a href="Sergei%20Meskhi">Sergei Meskhi</a>, were more radical than their predecessors in engaging in journalism, urban politics, and business, and according to historian <a href="Ronald%20Grigor%20Suny">Ronald Grigor Suny</a> they were "the first group of Georgian intellectuals to become involved primarily in the urban and economic life in Georgia.
They were supplanted by the <a href="Mesame%20Dasi">Mesame Dasi</a> (მესამე დასი, "Third Group"), which was composed mainly of Georgian <a href="social%20democrats">social democrats</a>.
